definition: to fight over/to rush/to scramble/to grab/to rob/to snatch
to take possession of/to occupy/to take up

sentences.english: But they have snatched the market niche for big, heavy-duty tires.
sentences.chinese: 但国内厂家抢占了重型轮胎市场。

sentences.english: While you're out leveling grab a quest each time you get.
sentences.chinese: 而你在外面找平抢占追求每一次当你得到的。

sentences.english: The emergency of online media has rapidly grabbed the survival space of article-based media.
sentences.chinese: 网络媒体出现后迅速抢占了纸质媒体的生存空间。

sentences.english: He grabbed off the best seat.
Certain critical sections of the kernel code are locked against preemption.
sentences.chinese: 可以锁定内核代码的关键部分，不允许抢占。

sentences.english: Preempt the application for very short deterministic periods.
sentences.chinese: 抢占应用程序一小段确定的时间。

sentences.english: For the government, the task is to get ahead of the crisis.
sentences.chinese: 对政府来说，首要任务就是要快速反应，抢占先机。

sentences.english: The kernel preemption case is handled by the spinlock code itself.
sentences.chinese: 内核的抢占机制被它自己操作自旋锁的代码所控制。

sentences.english: The creatures devourhuge quantities of plankton, thus depriving small fish of the food they need."This
sentences.chinese: 水母吞食大量浮游生物，抢占小鱼小虾的食物来源。

sentences.english: Leo sulks that Capricorn is at the head of the table.
sentences.chinese: 狮子座因被摩羯座抢占了餐桌的主位而忿忿不平。

sentences.english: It is a sure way to grab headlines and rattle the neighborhood.
sentences.chinese: 那是一个抢占头条和震撼毗邻地区最有效的方法。

sentences.english: Mike volunteered to detail your car. He also fumigated your room.
sentences.chinese: 迈克抢占了的你小车，他用烟熏了你的房间。

sentences.english: Enterprises have to seize market share.
However, Microsoft did not timely at this time to seize the beachhead Internet.
sentences.chinese: 但微软却并没有在此时及时的抢占互联网的滩头。

definition: to make an amphibious assault/to seize a beachhead/to gain a foothold in (a new market)
to take cities and seize territories (idiom)
rushing to stake one's claim in new markets
lit. late-comer lives above (idiom); the up-and-coming youngster outstrips the older generation/the pupil surpasses the master
to occupy by force/to seize/to dominate
to break new ground (for agriculture)/to open up (a new seam)/to develop (border regions)/fig. to open up (new horizons)
to rush (to do sth urgent)/to try to be the first/to forestall
to stand firmly/to gain a foothold/to establish oneself
to fight over/to rush/to scramble/to grab/to rob/to snatch
